message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inulin is the most accurate estimate for GFR because it is freely filtered and not reabsorbed, secreted, or metabolized by the kidneys. Glucose is filtered and partially reabsorbed in the kidneys, while PAH is both filtered and secreted by the kidneys. Sodium is also filtered and partially reabsorbed, making it a poor estimate for GFR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inulin is the most accurate estimate for GFR since it is freely filtered through the glomeruli and not secreted or reabsorbed in the renal tubules. Glucose is reabsorbed by the proximal tubules, PAH is actively secreted by the renal tubules, and sodium is not specific to GFR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, inulin is the most accurate estimate of GFR as it is freely filtered by the glomerulus but not absorbed or secreted. Glucose is also filtered but it is reabsorbed, while PAH is both filtered and secreted. Sodium is not filtered by the glomerulus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inulin is the most accurate estimate for GFR as it is freely filtered, not reabsorbed, secreted or metabolized by the kidneys. Glucose is reabsorbed and PAH is actively secreted. Sodium is also reabsorbed and not specific to kidney function evaluation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inulin is considered the gold standard for measuring GFR as it is freely filtered by the glomerulus and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules. Glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules and PAH is actively secreted by the tubules, leading to underestimation or overestimation of GFR respectively. Sodium is not a measure of GFR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inulin clearance is considered the gold standard for measuring GFR, as it is freely filtered by the glomeruli and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted by the renal tubules. Glucose is reabsorbed by the renal tubules, while PAH is both filtered and actively secreted by the tubules, making their clearances less accurate estimates of GFR. Sodium is not used as a marker for GFR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only inulin is freely filtered at the glomerulus and is not reabsorbed or secreted, making it an accurate estimate of GFR. Glucose is reabsorbed by the proximal tubule, while PAH is both filtered and secreted, and sodium is not specific to kidney function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inulin clearance is considered the most accurate estimate of GFR due to its complete filtration at the glomerulus and lack of reabsorption or secretion in the tubules. Glucose and sodium are reabsorbed in the tubules, while PAH is secreted in the tubules, which makes their clearance less accurate measures of GFR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, inulin is the most accurate estimate for GFR as it is freely filtered at the glomerulus and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted in the tubules. Glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal tubules, PAH is actively secreted in the proximal tubules, and sodium is reabsorbed in various parts of the nephron.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Inulin is considered the gold standard for measuring GFR, as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed, secreted, or metabolized by the kidneys. Glucose is also filtered and may be used to estimate GFR in diabetic patients, but it may not be accurate in those with impaired glucose handling. PAH is cleared by both filtration and secretion, so it overestimates GFR. Sodium is not filtered and is actively reabsorbed, so it underestimates GFR.
